001package squidpony.squidgrid.mapping;
002
003import squidpony.squidmath.Coord;
004import squidpony.squidmath.CoordPacker;
005import squidpony.squidmath.IRNG;
006import squidpony.squidmath.OrderedMap;
007
008import java.util.ArrayList;
009import java.util.List;
010
011/**
012 * Generate dungeons based on a random, winding, looping path through 2D space. Uses techniques from MixedGenerator.
013 * Uses a Moore Curve, which is related to Hilbert Curves but loops back to its starting point, and stretches and
014 * distorts the grid to make sure a visual correlation isn't obvious. This supports the getEnvironment() method, which
015 * can be used in conjunction with RoomFinder to find where separate room, corridor, and cave areas have been placed.
016 * <br>
017 * To get a sense of what kinds of map this generates, you can look at a sample map on
018 * https://gist.github.com/tommyettinger/93b47048fc8a209a9712 , which also includes a snippet of Java code that can
019 * generate that map.
020 * <br>
021 * The name comes from a vivid dream I had about gigantic, multi-colored snakes that completely occupied a roguelike
022 * dungeon. Shortly after, I made the connection to the Australian mythology I'd heard about the Rainbow Serpent, which
023 * in some stories dug water-holes and was similarly gigantic.
024 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 10/24/2015.
025 */
026public class SerpentMapGenerator implements IDungeonGenerator {
027    private MixedGenerator mix;
028    private int[] columns, rows;
029
030    /**
031     * This prepares a map generator that will generate a map with the given width and height, using the given IRNG.
032     * The intended purpose is to carve a long path that loops through the whole dungeon, while hopefully maximizing
033     * the amount of rooms the player encounters. You call the different carver-adding methods to affect what the
034     * dungeon will look like, putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(), and putRoundRoomCarvers(), defaulting to only
035     * caves if none are called. You call generate() after adding carvers, which returns a char[][] for a map.
036     *
037     * @param width  the width of the final map in cells
038     * @param height the height of the final map in cells
039     * @param rng    an IRNG object to use for random choices; this make a lot of random choices.
040     * @see MixedGenerator
041     */
042    public SerpentMapGenerator(int width, int height, IRNG rng) {
043        this(width, height, rng, false);
044    }
045
046    /**
047     * This prepares a map generator that will generate a map with the given width and height, using the given IRNG.
048     * The intended purpose is to carve a long path that loops through the whole dungeon, while hopefully maximizing
049     * the amount of rooms the player encounters. You call the different carver-adding methods to affect what the
050     * dungeon will look like, putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(), and putRoundRoomCarvers(), defaulting to only
051     * caves if none are called. You call generate() after adding carvers, which returns a char[][] for a map.
052     *
053     * @param width       the width of the final map in cells
054     * @param height      the height of the final map in cells
055     * @param random      an IRNG object to use for random choices; this make a lot of random choices.
056     * @param symmetrical true if this should generate a bi-radially symmetric map, false for a typical map
057     * @see MixedGenerator
058     */
059    public SerpentMapGenerator(int width, int height, IRNG random, boolean symmetrical) {
060        if (width <= 2 || height <= 2)
061            throw new IllegalArgumentException("width and height must be greater than 2");
062        CoordPacker.init();
063        long columnAlterations = random.nextLong() >>> 16;
064        float columnBase = width / (Long.bitCount(columnAlterations) + 48.0f);
065        long rowAlterations = random.nextLong() >>> 16;
066        float rowBase = height / (Long.bitCount(rowAlterations) + 48.0f);
067
068        columns = new int[16];
069        rows = new int[16];
070        int csum = 0, rsum = 0;
071        long b = 7;
072        for (int i = 0; i < 16; i++, b <<= 3) {
073            columns[i] = csum + (int) (columnBase * 0.5f * (3 + Long.bitCount(columnAlterations & b)));
074            csum += (int) (columnBase * (3 + Long.bitCount(columnAlterations & b)));
075            rows[i] = rsum + (int) (rowBase * 0.5f * (3 + Long.bitCount(rowAlterations & b)));
076            rsum += (int) (rowBase * (3 + Long.bitCount(rowAlterations & b)));
077        }
078        int cs = width - csum;
079        int rs = height - rsum;
080        int cs2 = cs, rs2 = rs, cs3 = cs, rs3 = rs;
081        for (int i = 0; i <= 7; i++) {
082            cs2 = 0;
083            rs2 = 0;
084            columns[i] -= cs2;
085            rows[i] -= rs2;
086        }
087        for (int i = 15; i >= 8; i--) {
088            cs3 = cs3 * (i - 8) / 8;
089            rs3 = rs3 * (i - 8) / 8;
090            columns[i] += cs3;
091            rows[i] += rs3;
092        }
093
094        List<Coord> points = new ArrayList<>(80);
095        Coord temp;
096        for (int i = 0, m = random.nextInt(64), r; i < 256; r = random.between(4, 12), i += r, m += r) {
097            temp = CoordPacker.mooreToCoord(m);
098            points.add(Coord.get(columns[temp.x], rows[temp.y]));
099        }
100        points.add(points.get(0));
101        if (symmetrical) {
102            mix = new SymmetryDungeonGenerator(width, height, random,
103                    SymmetryDungeonGenerator.removeSomeOverlap(width, height, points));
104        } else
105            mix = new MixedGenerator(width, height, random, points);
106    }
107
108    /**
109     * This prepares a map generator that will generate a map with the given width and height, using the given IRNG.
110     * The intended purpose is to carve a long path that loops through the whole dungeon, while hopefully maximizing
111     * the amount of rooms the player encounters. You call the different carver-adding methods to affect what the
112     * dungeon will look like, putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(), and putRoundRoomCarvers(), defaulting to only
113     * caves if none are called. You call generate() after adding carvers, which returns a char[][] for a map.
114     *
115     * @param width           the width of the final map in cells
116     * @param height          the height of the final map in cells
117     * @param rng             an IRNG object to use for random choices; this make a lot of random choices.
118     * @param branchingChance the chance from 0.0 to 1.0 that each room will branch at least once
119     * @see MixedGenerator
120     */
121    public SerpentMapGenerator(int width, int height, IRNG rng, double branchingChance) {
122        this(width, height, rng, branchingChance, false);
123    }
124
125    /**
126     * This prepares a map generator that will generate a map with the given width and height, using the given IRNG.
127     * The intended purpose is to carve a long path that loops through the whole dungeon, while hopefully maximizing
128     * the amount of rooms the player encounters. You call the different carver-adding methods to affect what the
129     * dungeon will look like, putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(), and putRoundRoomCarvers(), defaulting to only
130     * caves if none are called. You call generate() after adding carvers, which returns a char[][] for a map.
131     *
132     * @param width           the width of the final map in cells
133     * @param height          the height of the final map in cells
134     * @param random          an IRNG object to use for random choices; this make a lot of random choices.
135     * @param branchingChance the chance from 0.0 to 1.0 that each room will branch at least once
136     * @param symmetrical     true if this should generate a bi-radially symmetric map, false for a typical map
137     * @see MixedGenerator
138     */
139    public SerpentMapGenerator(int width, int height, IRNG random, double branchingChance, boolean symmetrical) {
140        if (width <= 2 || height <= 2)
141            throw new IllegalArgumentException("width and height must be greater than 2");
142        CoordPacker.init();
143        long columnAlterations = random.nextLong() >>> 16;
144        float columnBase = width / (Long.bitCount(columnAlterations) + 48.0f);
145        long rowAlterations = random.nextLong() >>> 16;
146        float rowBase = height / (Long.bitCount(rowAlterations) + 48.0f);
147
148        columns = new int[16];
149        rows = new int[16];
150        int csum = 0, rsum = 0;
151        long b = 7;
152        for (int i = 0; i < 16; i++, b <<= 3) {
153            columns[i] = csum + (int) (columnBase * 0.5f * (3 + Long.bitCount(columnAlterations & b)));
154            csum += (int) (columnBase * (3 + Long.bitCount(columnAlterations & b)));
155            rows[i] = rsum + (int) (rowBase * 0.5f * (3 + Long.bitCount(rowAlterations & b)));
156            rsum += (int) (rowBase * (3 + Long.bitCount(rowAlterations & b)));
157        }
158        int cs = width - csum;
159        int rs = height - rsum;
160        int cs2 = cs, rs2 = rs, cs3 = cs, rs3 = rs;
161        for (int i = 0; i <= 7; i++) {
162            cs2 = 0;
163            rs2 = 0;
164            columns[i] -= cs2;
165            rows[i] -= rs2;
166        }
167        for (int i = 15; i >= 8; i--) {
168            cs3 = cs3 * (i - 8) / 8;
169            rs3 = rs3 * (i - 8) / 8;
170            columns[i] += cs3;
171            rows[i] += rs3;
172        }
173
174        OrderedMap<Coord, List<Coord>> connections = new OrderedMap<>(80);
175        Coord temp, t;
176        int m = random.nextInt(64), r = random.between(4, 12);
177        temp = CoordPacker.mooreToCoord(m);
178        Coord starter = CoordPacker.mooreToCoord(m);
179        m += r;
180        for (int i = r; i < 256; i += r, m += r) {
181            List<Coord> cl = new ArrayList<>(4);
182            cl.add(Coord.get(columns[temp.x], rows[temp.y]));
183            temp = CoordPacker.mooreToCoord(m);
184            r = random.between(4, 12);
185            for (int j = 0, p = r - 1;
186                 j < 3 && p > 2 && Math.min(random.nextDouble(), random.nextDouble()) < branchingChance;
187                 j++, p -= random.between(1, p)) {
188                t = CoordPacker.mooreToCoord(m + p);
189                cl.add(Coord.get(columns[t.x], rows[t.y]));
190            }
191            connections.put(Coord.get(columns[temp.x], rows[temp.y]), cl);
192        }
193        connections.get(Coord.get(columns[temp.x], rows[temp.y])).add(
194                Coord.get(columns[starter.x], rows[starter.y]));
195        if (symmetrical) {
196            mix = new SymmetryDungeonGenerator(width, height, random,
197                    SymmetryDungeonGenerator.removeSomeOverlap(width, height, connections));
198        } else
199            mix = new MixedGenerator(width, height, random, connections);
200
201    }
202
203    /**
204     * Changes the number of "carvers" that will create caves from one room to the next. If count is 0 or less, no caves
205     * will be made. If count is at least 1, caves are possible, and higher numbers relative to the other carvers make
206     * caves more likely. Carvers are shuffled when used, then repeat if exhausted during generation. Since typically
207     * about 30-40 rooms are carved, large totals for carver count aren't really needed; aiming for a total of 10
208     * between the count of putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(), and putRoundRoomCarvers() is reasonable.
209     *
210     * @param count the number of carvers making caves between rooms; only matters in relation to other carvers
211     * @see MixedGenerator
212     */
213    public void putCaveCarvers(int count) {
214        mix.putCaveCarvers(count);
215    }
216
217    /**
218     * Changes the number of "carvers" that will create right-angle corridors from one room to the next, create rooms
219     * with a random size in a box shape at the start and end, and a small room at the corner if there is one. If count
220     * is 0 or less, no box-shaped rooms will be made. If count is at least 1, box-shaped rooms are possible, and higher
221     * numbers relative to the other carvers make box-shaped rooms more likely. Carvers are shuffled when used, then
222     * repeat if exhausted during generation. Since typically about 30-40 rooms are carved, large totals for carver
223     * count aren't really needed; aiming for a total of 10 between the count of putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(),
224     * and putRoundRoomCarvers() is reasonable.
225     *
226     * @param count the number of carvers making box-shaped rooms and corridors between them; only matters in relation
227     *              to other carvers
228     * @see MixedGenerator
229     */
230    public void putBoxRoomCarvers(int count) {
231        mix.putBoxRoomCarvers(count);
232    }
233
234    /**
235     * Changes the number of "carvers" that will create right-angle corridors from one room to the next, create rooms
236     * with a random size in a box shape at the start and end, and a small room at the corner if there is one. This also
237     * ensures walls will be placed around the room, only allowing corridors and small cave openings to pass. If count
238     * is 0 or less, no box-shaped rooms will be made. If count is at least 1, box-shaped rooms are possible, and higher
239     * numbers relative to the other carvers make box-shaped rooms more likely. Carvers are shuffled when used, then
240     * repeat if exhausted during generation. Since typically about 30-40 rooms are carved, large totals for carver
241     * count aren't really needed; aiming for a total of 10 between the count of putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(),
242     * and putRoundRoomCarvers() is reasonable.
243     *
244     * @param count the number of carvers making box-shaped rooms and corridors between them; only matters in relation
245     *              to other carvers
246     * @see MixedGenerator
247     */
248    public void putWalledBoxRoomCarvers(int count) {
249        mix.putWalledBoxRoomCarvers(count);
250    }
251
252    /**
253     * Changes the number of "carvers" that will create right-angle corridors from one room to the next, create rooms
254     * with a random size in a circle shape at the start and end, and a small circular room at the corner if there is
255     * one. If count is 0 or less, no circular rooms will be made. If count is at least 1, circular rooms are possible,
256     * and higher numbers relative to the other carvers make circular rooms more likely. Carvers are shuffled when used,
257     * then repeat if exhausted during generation. Since typically about 30-40 rooms are carved, large totals for carver
258     * count aren't really needed; aiming for a total of 10 between the count of putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(),
259     * and putRoundRoomCarvers() is reasonable.
260     *
261     * @param count the number of carvers making circular rooms and corridors between them; only matters in relation
262     *              to other carvers
263     * @see MixedGenerator
264     */
265    public void putRoundRoomCarvers(int count) {
266        mix.putRoundRoomCarvers(count);
267    }
268
269    /**
270     * Changes the number of "carvers" that will create right-angle corridors from one room to the next, create rooms
271     * with a random size in a circle shape at the start and end, and a small circular room at the corner if there is
272     * one. This also ensures walls will be placed around the room, only allowing corridors and small cave openings to
273     * pass. If count is 0 or less, no circular rooms will be made. If count is at least 1, circular rooms are possible,
274     * and higher numbers relative to the other carvers make circular rooms more likely. Carvers are shuffled when used,
275     * then repeat if exhausted during generation. Since typically about 30-40 rooms are carved, large totals for carver
276     * count aren't really needed; aiming for a total of 10 between the count of putCaveCarvers(), putBoxRoomCarvers(),
277     * and putRoundRoomCarvers() is reasonable.
278     *
279     * @param count the number of carvers making circular rooms and corridors between them; only matters in relation
280     *              to other carvers
281     * @see MixedGenerator
282     */
283    public void putWalledRoundRoomCarvers(int count) {
284        mix.putWalledRoundRoomCarvers(count);
285    }
286
287    /**
288     * This generates a new map by stretching a 16x16 grid of potential rooms to fit the width and height passed to the
289     * constructor, randomly expanding columns and rows before contracting the whole to fit perfectly. This uses the
290     * Moore Curve, a space-filling curve that loops around on itself, to guarantee that the rooms will always have a
291     * long path through the dungeon that, if followed completely, will take you back to your starting room. Some small
292     * branches are possible, and large rooms may merge with other rooms nearby. This uses MixedGenerator.
293     *
294     * @return a char[][] where '#' is a wall and '.' is a floor or corridor; x first y second
295     * @see MixedGenerator
296     */
297    public char[][] generate() {
298        return mix.generate();
299    }
300
301
302    /**
303     * Gets a 2D array of int constants, each representing a type of environment corresponding to a static field of
304     * MixedGenerator. This array will have the same size as the last char 2D array produced by generate(); the value
305     * of this method if called before generate() is undefined, but probably will be a 2D array of all 0 (UNTOUCHED).
306     * <ul>
307     * <li>MixedGenerator.UNTOUCHED, equal to 0, is used for any cells that aren't near a floor.</li>
308     * <li>MixedGenerator.ROOM_FLOOR, equal to 1, is used for floor cells inside wide room areas.</li>
309     * <li>MixedGenerator.ROOM_WALL, equal to 2, is used for wall cells around wide room areas.</li>
310     * <li>MixedGenerator.CAVE_FLOOR, equal to 3, is used for floor cells inside rough cave areas.</li>
311     * <li>MixedGenerator.CAVE_WALL, equal to 4, is used for wall cells around rough cave areas.</li>
312     * <li>MixedGenerator.CORRIDOR_FLOOR, equal to 5, is used for floor cells inside narrow corridor areas.</li>
313     * <li>MixedGenerator.CORRIDOR_WALL, equal to 6, is used for wall cells around narrow corridor areas.</li>
314     * </ul>
315     *
316     * @return a 2D int array where each element is an environment type constant in MixedGenerator
317     */
318    public int[][] getEnvironment() {
319        return mix.getEnvironment();
320    }
321
322    public char[][] getDungeon() {
323        return mix.getDungeon();
324    }
325}
